The 2020 #BestColleges rankings are here. New this year is the Top Performers in Social Mobility ranking. The new ranking evaluates which schools best serve underrepresented students. Using Pell Grants as a proxy measure, the ranking looks at enrollment and graduation rates of low-income students. Schools in the University of California system, including Riverside, Santa Cruz and Irvine, all succeed in this area. Tied for No. 4 on the list are the University of La Verne in California, Howard University in the District of Columbia and Rutgers University‚ÄîNewark in New Jersey.

For more about the #BestColleges, head to the link in our bio. (Collin Howell for USN&WR)

The number of children suffering from cancer around the world ‚Äì including in wealthy countries like the United States ‚Äì is far greater than previously believed. New research estimates that more than 400,000 new cases of children with cancer annually occur around the world, a figure roughly twice the amount of cases that are diagnosed.

In a special report, U.S. News traveled to four parts of the world to examine the barriers to treating children with cancer, and successful strategies being used to improve outcomes for sick children. (üì∑: Yue Wu @yuewoo)

Follow the link in our bio to see the full package, with reporting spanning six countries across three continents.

Today, U.S. News published a special report examining the toll of childhood cancer around the world. From Lebanon and Jordan to Hong Kong and the U.S., this project covers current efforts to improve care for patients battling childhood cancer and offer pathways to hope.

Pictured left to right: Fatima, who in early 2016 was hospitalized with a fever that turned out to be a symptom of leukemia in Lebanon; Fabrice, who was diagnosed with kidney cancer in Rwanda in 2013; Peter (seen as a toddler in an old photograph), who was 8-years-old when he was diagnosed with leukemia in Liberia; and Noureddine, who at 17 became sick with a stomach ache and flu-like symptoms that eventually led to a diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma, a highly aggressive form of cancer, in Jordan.

Follow the link in our bio to read their stories and stories of children like them battling cancer around the world. (üì∑: Natalie Naccache @natnacphotos; Jacques Nkinzingabo @jack_yakubu1; Carielle Doe @cariyell; Nadia Bseiso @nadiabseiso)

Millions of kids around the country are heading back to school this week, and with it brings annual back-to-school shopping trips. According to the Back-to-School 2019 survey from the National Retail Federation, families will spend close to $700 on average for supplies, clothing, shoes and tech, with total spending for K-12 schools and college combined expected to reach $80.7 billion. You can save by taking stock of what you already have at home, spreading out back-to-school purchases and comparing prices. For more tips about back-to-school shopping, visit the link in our bio. Scientists studying the melting of the ice in Greenland this summer are finding themselves working in shirtsleeve weather without the need for gloves. Summer this year has brought record-shattering heat and extreme melt to Greenland. By the end of summer, about 440 billion tons of ice will have melted or calved off Greenland's giant ice sheet, scientists estimate. That's enough water to flood Pennsylvania or the country of Greece about a foot deep.

Yield curves on the U.S. and U.K. bonds inverted Wednesday for the first time in a decade, a development typically considered to be a bad omen for what lies ahead in the next year or two. In the U.S., inversions have preceded almost every recession since the 1950s.

Trade tensions between the U.S. and China continue to cause volatility in global markets. | Aug. 15, 2019 | New York City |

President Donald Trump was facing a potentially very bad news cycle, with special counsel Robert Mueller preparing to testify before Congress and a past friend, Jeffrey Epstein, charged with sexually molesting underage girls. So he went on a rant about four minority, female members of Congress, calling on them at rallies and in tweets to "go back" to their countries of origin.

It was a classic Trump move: distract, divert, repeat. When a presidential problem surfaces, the president finds a way to move the problem out of the public eye, relieving pressure on him to solve the actual problem.

But two and a half years into his tumultuous presidency, Trump is finding that problems at home and abroad are mounting, getting harder to obscure. And with the presidential campaign heating up, the president is getting daily criticism from two dozen people who want his job.

Follow the link in our bio for the full story on how Trump's distraction strategy could be fraying. (üì∑: Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Father‚Äôs Day is a once-a-year celebration of the bond between Dad and his kids, but cementing that bond takes a year-round commitment.

A new study suggests the type of involvement (caregiving vs. play) and the timing (workday vs. weekend) make a difference.

University of Georgia researchers found that dads who take time off work to be with their kids strengthen the bond between them.

While fathers who play with their kids on days off do build strong relationships, those who spend time caring for them during the workweek appear to develop the best ones, according to study author Geoffrey Brown.

1 in every 5 Americans will develop skin cancer throughout their lifetime.

The American Academy of Dermatology recommends that any time you‚Äôre outdoors, you should wear a sunscreen that is broad-spectrum, at least SPF 30 and water resistant. A recent study shows daily sunscreen use helps reduce the risk of developing melanoma, the rarest but most deadly form of skin cancer. Sunscreen use also helps prevent the development of squamous cell carcinoma, one of the most common types of skin cancer.

May is skin cancer awareness month, and as the weather heats up and you head out to enjoy the outdoors, you should review the best ways to stay safe in the sun. For tips on how to protect your skin, head to the link in our bio.
(üñºTori Smith for USN&WR)

"Sadly, I have not been able to do so." Read more at the link in our bio. (üì∏: Alastair Grant/AP)

The classroom is where many Americans learn to read, write, perform arithmetic and speak a foreign language. So can it also be the place where they master important financial concepts such as how to manage debt, improve credit, take out student loans and plan for retirement?

For many politicians, educators and financial literacy advocates, this question has created a push for financial education in elementary, high school and college classrooms, community centers and through counseling, seminars and workshops.

April is Financial Literacy Month. For a look at how you can improve your financial literacy and how Americans can get a better grasp on financial literacy, head to the link in our bio. (üñº: Tori Smith for USN&WR)

As Notre Dame burned, Parisians watched. The more than 850-year-old cathedral caught on fire on Monday and many Parisians watched from across the Seine as firefighters worked to put out the fire. Already efforts are underway to raise funds to restore the historic church. For more, see the link in our bio. (üì∏ Getty Images and AP)

This weekend, the international community marked 25 years since the 100-day Rwandan genocide that claimed an estimated 800,000 lives. One of the darkest chapters in modern history began on April 6, 1994, when the plane carrying Rwandan President Juv√©nal Habyarimana was shot down. The following day the Hutu-majority government directed killings that primarily targeted the ethnic minority Tutsis, moderate Hutus and other groups. In this gallery of images, USN photo editors curated portraits of genocide survivors from 1994 alongside photos of victims and human remains displayed at the Kigali Genocide Memorial which serve as a stark reminder of the horrors of the genocide. (üì∏ Getty Images)

Long considered among the most exclusive communities in central Tennessee, Williamson County had the 22nd-highest overall score in the country, and was the only Tennessee locality to crack the Healthiest Communities top 500. 
There‚Äôs little question that Williamson County‚Äôs wealth and its abundance of college-educated residents ‚Äì two data points that often translate to positive health outcomes ‚Äì are key to its impressive Healthiest Communities scores. But even a healthy community faces challenges. 
Find out more about Williamson County at the link in our bio. (üì∏: @willdeshazer for USN&WR)

Madison County ranks seventh among 29 Appalachian counties in North Carolina when measured across the 81 factors used to determine the Healthiest Communities rankings. At least some of that success is likely due to the Hot Springs Health Program, which was established in 1971 by a pair of nurse practitioners and today stretches across four sites.

Read more about Madison County and its beloved Hot Springs Health Program at the link in our bio. (üì∏: Andy McMillan for USN&WR)

Home to 1.4 million people and one of two independent counties on Long Island, Nassau County, New York, is the picture of community well-being: The area is relatively safe, the unemployment rate is fairly low and most people have health coverage. For the past several years, American attention has been fixated on fighting opioid overdoses in largely white towns, where reports of climbing fatality rates have struck like a thunderbolt, revealing communities in economic and social distress.

Yet population health analysts, academics and on-the-ground specialists say heroin and its related plagues of crime and death have stalked African-American neighborhoods for decades, garnering little to no attention. And when the government has bothered to address it in cities like Chicago, critics say, it's usually through police crackdowns on users and dealers rather than increased access to intervention, drug treatment or badly needed economic aid.

The disparities in attention, resources and long-term strategies have led to a tale of two opioid crises. One is white, a malady of medical and mental health, and worthy of a White House-level task force. The other is black, criminal and largely ignored, even as statistics show black opioid users are dying at a skyrocketing pace.

‚ÄúWe've never seen anything like it before ‚Äì it's the largest increase of any substance that we've ever measured in the past 43 years," says Richard Miech, a University of Michigan researcher and principal investigator for the Monitoring the Future survey.

When Harold Collins flew into Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport with nearly 70 fellow veterans on Oct. 18 of last year, he received a welcome far different than when he returned from Vietnam after his service in the Army. The war veteran was greeted with applause and a performance by a 20-man chorus. Collins had traveled to Washington, D.C., from Florida through the Honor Flight Network, a nonprofit organization committed to fulfilling veterans' dreams of visiting their respective memorials free of cost. The airport reception, and the many times he heard "thank you for your service" throughout the day, was more than Collins expected. After his time in Vietnam, where he was a soldier in the Army's 1st Infantry Division and also worked as a cryptologist, "we were told to take off our uniform because people would dislike you for serving in the military," Collins, who also served in the Korean War, explained. "In a way [this trip] makes up for it. We get the welcome home we didn't get when we got back [from Vietnam]." Click the link in our bio for more on how hundreds of thousands of veterans around the nation are gaining similar experiences. (üì∑: @lydiache)

Before leaving the White House on Friday, U.S. President Donald Trump told reporters that he had signed an order to deny asylum to migrants who enter the country illegally. In doing so, Trump ‚Äúinvoked extraordinary national security powers to deny asylum to migrants who enter the country illegally, tightening the border as caravans of Central Americans slowly approach the United States,‚Äù the Associated Press writes. In this Nov. 5. 2018, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection agent stands in front of a sign that reads ‚ÄúWelcome to the United States‚Äù during a training exercise at the U.S.-Mexico border. Trump ordered troops to the border weeks before the possible arrival of a migrant caravan which started on Oct. 12, when a group of 160 Hondurans left the town of San Pedro Sula. Since then, at least two other caravans have formed and thousands of migrants are moving north towards the U.S. Click the link in our bio for more images from photographers following the migrant caravan. (üì∑: John Moore/Getty Images)

Voters will send a historic 100-plus women to Congress, including at least 98 women to the House, an all-time high, and a dozen to the U.S. Senate. The results overtake the historic "Year of the Woman" in 1992, which resulted in a then-record 54 women in Congress. Soaring voter turnout this year sent a new and diverse class of national and state leaders into office, breaking barriers. Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib will share the title of first Muslim women in Congress. Tlaib will also be the first Palestinian-American congresswoman. In a tweet Tuesday night, Omar congratulated Tlaib, writing, ‚ÄúI cannot wait to serve with you, inshallah.‚Äù They‚Äôll serve alongside Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who, at 29, will be the youngest woman elected to Congress. Sharice Davids and Deb Haaland will also make history as the nation‚Äôs first Native American congresswomen. Click the link in our bio for a look at more historic firsts from the 2018 midterm elections. (üì∑: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images; Paul Sancya, File/AP; Rick Loomis/Getty Images; Colin E. Braley/AP; Mark Ralston/AFP/Getty Images)

Colorado made history Tuesday night, electing the nation‚Äôs first openly gay governor. Rep. Jared Polis, D-Colorado, became the first openly gay person to be elected governor, beating Republican Walker Stapleton to replace Gov. John Hickenlooper, a Democrat. ‚ÄúI think it really gives Colorado an opportunity to stick a thumb in the eye of Mike Pence, whose view of America is not as inclusive as where America is today," Polis told Colorado Democrats earlier this year in a speech. And that‚Äôs not all supporters of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rights had to celebrate. Kim Davis, a darling of the anti-gay marriage movement and the Kentucky County clerk who spent five days in jail after refusing to obey the 2015 Supreme Court ruling making same-sex marriage the law of the land, was rejected by Rowan County voters for another term. "Good riddance to her discriminatory nonsense and disrespect for law and order," Charlotte Clymer, press secretary for the Human Right Campaign, said on Twitter in response to the news. Click the link in our bio for more. (üì∑: AAron Ontiveroz/The Denver Post/Getty Images)

Education probably isn‚Äôt the issue driving you to the polls this 2018 midterm election. In fact, a¬†Gallup poll published in October reported that only 2 percent of voters named education as the most important problem in the U.S. But the election will have sweeping ramifications for education policy in potentially dozens of states across the country. For starters, voters in 36 states will cast a ballot for a governor, and their votes will elevate someone new to the governor's mansion in at least 17 of those states where the current governor is either term-limited or not running for re-election. many of those¬†governors appoint state education leaders. Seven states ‚Äì Arizona, California, Georgia, Idaho, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Wyoming ‚Äì are holding elections for the position of chief state school officer. And governors appoint the state board of education in 25 states. What does this mean for policy? "This is a change election," says Kristen Amundson, president and CEO of the National School Board Association. Click the link in our bio for more on how your vote this Election Day is a vote for education. (üì∑: Jessica McGowan/Getty Images)

Andrew Gillum‚Äôs first serious act of political defiance came 18 years ago when he crashed the office he's now on the cusp of occupying himself, confronting a governor by the name of Jeb Bush. Just a 20-year-old college sophomore at the time, Gillum was one of four students who stormed the governor's office in Tallahassee and vowed to wait as long as possible to push for changes to Bush's plan to dismantle affirmative action preferences. With hundreds of chanting students circling the rotunda outside in protest, Bush quickly granted not only a meeting, but a few substantive concessions ‚Äì promising the measure would be reviewed every three years and pledging support for legislation to pay for SAT preparatory courses for disadvantaged high school kids. Gillum emerged claiming a step in the right direction, but also unfulfilled. From the start, Gillum's underdog campaign for governor of Florida was always predicated on the same unsatisfied defiance that fueled his earliest days as an activist. Click the link in our bio for more on the man on the cusp of history in Florida. (üì∑: Lynne Sladky/AP)

Olympia, the capital of Washington, is a small art and culture center, but its problems track Seattle, the state's biggest city. Petty crimes linked to homelessness, chemical dependency and mental illness fill the courts with nonviolent offenders. Over the past few years, Olympians have united to do something about that, starting with community courts. Community courts can be found around the world in cities including Be'er Sheva, Israel; Christchurch, New Zealand; and Cape Town, South Africa. In the U.S., interest is growing. Instead of doing time, offenders do community service for restitution. Judges order them to attend and complete rehabilitation, therapeutic and educational programs. Over months and sometimes years, they learn they're not in it alone, and that they have neighbors with money and influence who invest in them. Here, offenders tend a communal garden to grow vegetables they share with local food banks. The gardening shows "they are important to us and they have a future. They can change things for themselves," says court executive Diane Whaley. Click the link in our bio for more on the holistic take on specialized courts. (üì∑: Olympia Community Court)

@knoxcollege1837‚Äôs academic calendar is broken into three 10-week trimesters, and students take three classes at a time. Everyone must complete one of the Galesburg, Illinois college‚Äôs 40-plus majors and either a minor or a second major. Preceptorial is an interdisciplinary class required of all first-year students that aims to prepare them to think critically and see diverse perspectives around topics like The American Dream or The Challenge of Sustainability. From there, undergrads fulfill requirements in the arts, humanities, the sciences, writing and more. Students also complete at least one experiential learning opportunity with a beyond-the-classroom component. Options include internships, study abroad experiences and community service. In the above photo, Nola Thompson works on garments in the college‚Äôs costume shop. Click the link in our bio for more about Knox College. (üì∑: @bziegler)

Germany‚Äôs Angela Merkel has announced that she will step down from her party's top spot this year and will not seek another appointment as chancellor after her term ends in 2021.¬†Merkel, 64, was¬†sworn in for her fourth term as chancellor in March after a razor-thin majority in Germany's parliament elected her to the position. Now, ‚Äúwe have entered the twilight territory where it's time to begin looking back at her legacy,‚Äù writes @BrettBruen. A leader of Germany's remarkable economic growth, European integration and the Western world order are among the consequential contributions that can undoubtedly be cited. She is also one of the planet's most powerful women at a time when society is finally confronting the injustice and inequity that women have lived with for so long. But the German chancellor‚Äôs greatest contribution to public service may be that her brand transcends gender. Click the link in our bio for more on the role Merkel has played in changing the perception of women leaders. (üì∑: Sean Gallup/Getty Images)

Test scores used to be the only way into college. Not anymore. Now, many universities are doing away with the¬†requirement. More than 1,000 schools have adopted test-optional admissions policies amid reignited concerns over whether there's a mismatch between what students learn in school and what college entrance exams ask of them, whether the tests are an accurate barometer of college readiness, and ‚Äì from an equity standpoint ‚Äì whether the tests present an advantage to those with more means. Potentially complicating the future of college entrance exams even further is the ongoing lawsuit against Harvard University, in which the plaintiffs argue that the school's race-conscious admissions policy discriminates against Asian-Americans. Part of the argument includes a claim that Asian-American applicants score higher than white applicants on the SAT but are admitted at a lower rate ‚Äì an accusation Harvard denies. Some in the college admissions world have predicted that a loss for Harvard, and the ensuing elimination of race-conscious admissions policies, would open the floodgates for schools going test-optional. Click the link in our bio for more on the future of college entrance exams. (üì∑: @bziegler)

Singapore is experiencing a trash crisis. Some predict the world's second most-densely populated city will run out of room in its landfill by 2035. According to figures from the country's National Environment Agency, while recycling rates for food waste are going up in Singapore, residents still threw away 676,800 metric tons of food in 2017. Only 16 percent of this was recycled ‚Äì the rest went to the landfill. Yet there may be a solution, according to a group of urban farmers and scientists in this Southeast Asian city-state, and it's one that has been buzzing under everyone's noses all along. Maggots. Click the link in our bio for more on Singapore‚Äôs love affair with larvae. (üì∑: Courtesy of Insectta)

Teaching extends beyond the classroom in a number of ways at the @universityofvermont. Students can participate in hands-on learning experiences on the peak of nearby Mount Mansfield or UVM‚Äôs aquatic research vessel Melosira. ‚ÄúStudents sense the enthusiasm from professors who are engaged with their work‚Äù as both teachers and scholars, says Kathy Fox, associate dean of the College of Arts and Sciences and a sociology professor. Fox has taught a justice studies class to UVM undergrads and women from the nearby Chittenden Regional Correctional Facility based on her research on reintegrating prisoners into society. In this photo, students tour the campus green house as part of a food systems class. For more about the University of Vermont, click the link in our bio. (üì∑: @bziegler)

Sandra Day O‚ÄôConnor, the first woman to serve on the U.S. Supreme Court, has announced that she has ‚Äúthe beginning stages of dementia, probably Alzheimer‚Äôs disease‚Äù and is stepping back from public life. In a public letter she explained that she can no longer be a leader in the push for youth civic engagement but called on others to take up the cause. ‚ÄúIt is my great hope that our nation will commit to educating our youth about civics, and to helping young people understand their crucial role as informed, active citizens in our nation,‚Äù she wrote. O‚ÄôConnor, 88, was nominated to the nation‚Äôs highest court in 1981 and announced her retirement in 2005. In 2016, O‚ÄôConnor penned a piece in U.S. News & World Report about the importance of the rule of law in stabilizing nations, and why we must make America‚Äôs courts ‚Äúas fair and just as they can be.‚Äù Click the link in our bio to read her thoughts. (üì∑: Chick Harrity, Darryl Heikes and Charlie Archambault for U.S. News & World Report)

Welcome to the State Fair of Texas. Every year, nearly 3 million people head to Dallas‚Äô historic Fair Park to experience Americana on display with its twirling rides, cowboy hats and a variety of fried foods. By some accounts, though, these attendance figures are questionable at best ‚Äì a 2016 Baylor University study notes that there is no evidence that the numbers provided by the fair are accurate ‚Äì and the fair holds a complex relationship with its neighbors. Fair Park, owned by the city of Dallas, and the 24-day fair held within its 277 acres have long been points of contention in Dallas. The city‚Äôs most iconic event is held in one of its lowest-income neighborhoods, and it‚Äôs not all fun and games for the surrounding community. Here, U.S. News photographers take you inside the shadows of the State Fair of Texas. Click the link in our bio for more on what it‚Äôs actually like to have the Texas state fair in your backyard. (üì∑: @lydiache, @brownisgood, @brandonthibodeaux and @bziegler)

Saudi ruler Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman and his government have offered no indication that allegations of involvement in the kidnapping and reported murder of dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi at a Saudi consulate in Turkey will affect the kingdom's future policies. The kingdom has come under international condemnation before ‚Äì and has weathered the controversies. And, despite widespread and enduring international condemnation, Saudi Arabia‚Äôs most important supporters appear willing to help contain the outrage. In this Oct. 15 photograph, a security guard passes a document to a colleague outside the Saudi Arabian Consulate. According to Turkish authorities, Turkey and Saudi Arabia pledged to conduct a joint "inspection" of the consulate where Khashoggi went missing, and Turkish officials have since described brutal scenes of his alleged torture and killing. Khashoggi was a U.S. legal resident, outspoken critic of the Saudi government and regular contributor to The Washington Post. Click the link in our bio for more on why Saudi Arabia shows no signs of changing. (üì∑: Petros Giannakouris/AP)

Get a glimpse of Middlebury College in Vermont. The "City of Excellence," as Plano bills itself, is not just lucky, officials say. The city's success is all about very careful planning ‚Äì decisions to manage the city's tremendous growth in a way that promotes economic development while keeping a sense of community. And it's a model, Planophiles say, which other growing cities can adopt to achieve a sort of civic work-life balance. "We have a unique value of being a very strong business community that also has a very strong small town, community focus," says Shannah Hayley, Plano's director of marketing and community engagement. "It's a weird mishmash." Click the link in our bio for more on the 69th biggest city in the nation ‚Äì and the ninth largest in Texas. (üì∑: Raja Roy for U.S. News & World Report)

Plano, Texas, reflects the growing diversity of its population, with Asian and Hispanic grocery stores and restaurants and libraries that offer storytime in Hindi, Chinese and Spanish. In many ways, Plano itself is emblematic of a demographic shift in Texas as a whole, with increases in the young-adult populations, growth in the Hispanic and Asian populations and a drop in poverty. And it is the influx of young adults, combined with Texas's high Latino population, that has political analysts and demographers wondering if this longtime bastion of conservatism is beginning to take on a politically bluish hue. A finalist for the South Asian Journalists Association‚Äôs outstanding enterprise reporting about South Asia award, U.S. News reporter Devon Haynie¬†explored Sri Lanka‚Äôs political fate on the 8-year anniversary of the Sri Lankan civil war in her May 2017 piece, ‚ÄúFacing Sri Lanka‚Äôs Ghosts.‚Äù What she found was grim. ‚ÄúAt some point during its brutal 26 years, the Sri Lankan civil war brought terror or loss to virtually everyone in the country,‚Äù writes Haynie. ‚ÄúAnd eight years after the war's end, grieving family members have still received no information about their missing loved ones, let alone justice for their disappearances.‚Äù Pictured here, Kasipillai Jeyavanitha had not seen her daughter, Jeromy, in years. When Dreahma Marshall‚Äôs family moved recently, she was relieved to find a C.O.O.L. Zone (short for "children overcoming obstacles and limits") at her son's new school. "I think every school should have it, and not just in elementary," says Marshall, whose son Darius Turner joined the Edgewood Primary School program as a kindergartner when he was having trouble sitting still and would get up and "talk to everybody." Nearly 1 in 5 kids in the U.S. experiences a mental, emotional or behavioral disorder like ADHD in a given year. Sometimes the issues are mild and temporary; increasingly they are serious and even life-threatening. Yet regardless of severity, most kids don't receive any specialized treatment. Hospitals are aiming their efforts at early interventions while also scrambling to manage an influx of youth walking through their doors seeking mental and behavioral health care. Here, Darius, with his mom looking on, sits in the "igloo" where kids can calm down during school. Click the link in our bio to read how rising rates of mental health and behavioral issues are prompting worry ‚Äì and action. (üì∑: Scott Goldsmith for U.S. News & World Report)

A washing machine, a mattress, a furnace, a sewing machine, a refrigerator, a car door, a car engine and a car. These are just a few of the things that Dan Wire, a supervisor with the Parks and Recreation Department, has found in Fort Wayne‚Äôs rivers. "I can remember as a kid, seeing something wiggling in the water," says Wire, who calls himself the city's river janitor. "It was an antenna ‚Äì and sure enough it was a Volkswagen Beetle." Wire has played a leading role in the city‚Äôs efforts to save - and capitalize on - its rivers. For him, Fort Wayne‚Äôs rivers are an asset, a unique natural resource that can energize the public and draw new people to this midsize city in the heart of the Rust Belt. City leaders agree. Next summer, Fort Wayne will complete the first phase of a $26 million riverfront development project officials hope will play a key role in ongoing efforts to revitalize downtown. As we kick off our new ‚ÄúCities‚Äù section at U.S. News, read about riverfront revitalization as a tool for economic growth in Rust Belt cities. Click the link in our bio for more. (üì∑: @devonhaynie)

Attending school in the Sunshine State means that students are likely to enjoy a good bit of time at the beach along with strong academics and plenty of opportunities for hands-on learning. From time immemorial, cities have been the central gathering places of human life, from where the great ideas and movements of the world have sprouted. Now for the first time in history, more people are living in cities than rural areas. And, this way of living is only going to continue: by 2050, the urban share of global population is projected to surpass 66 percent (up from 30 percent in 1950). Without doubt, urban life is increasingly defining the future of this country. At a time when Americans face gridlock in the nation‚Äôs capital, cities must continue to serve as our core workshops to test and implement new ideas and innovative programs within this new 21st century economy, writes @USNews Chairman Eric Gentler. For all the various urban issues with which we must grapple, cities remain our greatest economic drivers to create jobs and raise income and living standards. Click the link in our bio for more on why our growing cities matter. (üì∑: @bziegler)

There are some similarities between New Mexico‚Äôs neighboring Grant and Luna counties. Activists embraced after sharing stories of sexual abuse at the Hart Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill. Flowers and notes supporting Christine Blasey Ford sat on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court. Hundreds of protesters rallied in downtown Washington Thursday as the world watched Ford and Brett Kavanaugh deliver testimonies in a small hearing room. Data show white people in the U.S. tend to live in communities that have a better chance of being healthy ‚Äì but that‚Äôs not the case in Martin County, Kentucky. Established long ago as coal country, the rural community is home to myriad hollows and approximately 11,500 residents, and is the country‚Äôs worst-performing majority-white county in a U.S. News Healthiest Communities analysis of race, ethnicity and place in America. A longstanding mindset among area residents is to hope for more but accept poor outcomes, making positive change a difficult prospect. Despite what the statistics show, though, current and former residents say Martin County can thrive. Pointing to the potential of its industrial park, increased awareness about its water and infrastructure issues, and the construction of a new county high school ‚Äì along with the inherent resilience of its residents ‚Äì locals say opportunity exists for an Appalachian transformation. Click the link in our bio for more. (üì∑: @bziegler)

Four Georgia counties feature significant black populations and are among the nation's Healthiest Communities. Cobb, Paulding, Fayette and Columbia buck the national trend. Their residents have access to affordable housing and high incomes. Many also hold college degrees, indicating some economic and education factors can be more critical than race when it comes to predicting health outcomes. All sit near Atlanta, the city known as the South‚Äôs ‚Äúblack mecca.‚Äù Of course, even in counties that have larger African-American populations and appear to be doing better than anywhere else, longstanding Southern traditions and racial tension are still present, shaping the nuanced roles race, affluence and other social factors play in creating a community‚Äôs overall quality of life. In this series of merged home, business and personal portraits by photographer @joshua_rashaad, black residents weigh in on their quality of life ‚Äì where their communities succeed, and where they still have ground to gain. Click the link in our bio for more.

Racial and ethnic minorities face widespread disparities in health outcomes and care. For places with substantial shares of black residents, some of the strongest predictors of overall community health and well-being are also some of the areas that those places struggle with most, such as homicide rates, low birth weight and, in particular, access to healthy and affordable food. Linked to factors like these, disparities in health create "almost a genocide against black men," says Jiana Murdic, an advocate for equitable wellness in Philadelphia. The relationship to overall community well-being changes depending on the share of white, Hispanic, Native American and Asian residents in a community. Click the link in our bio for more on the relationship between race and community health. (Illustration by @lydiache with Getty Images)

Mexico's ancient system of floating islands, known as Chinampas, spread over more than seven times the area of New York City's Central Park. The waters and green space offer easy contact with nature, an antidote to greenhouse gases and perennial flooding and access to locally grown food. In Mexico City, this system of canals and floating islands is increasingly considered an asset vital to the city‚Äôs future. But they're increasingly under threat by illegal development, pollution and the city's growing population. "Without the Chinampas, there's no Mexico City," says Alberto Gonz√°lez Pozo, a professor at the¬†National Autonomous University of Mexico¬†and leading expert on the floating islands. Here, Benjamin Cristobal steers a boat along the Xochimilco canals. Click the link in our bio to read how dozens of locals are doing their part to preserve this endangered environmental asset. (üì∑: Ginnette Riquelme)

Native peoples in Fany Kuiru Castro‚Äôs South American homeland have been moved off their ancestral territories. "The best land has been taken by the ranchers and the palm oil and sugarcane companies,‚Äù the indigenous activist from¬†Colombia, explains. The plight of many of Colombia's myriad indigenous ethnic groups epitomizes those of landless first peoples around the world, from¬†Canada to¬†Chile, Namibia to the¬†Philippines. In many cases, it has precipitated well documented public health crises, including malnutrition, alcoholism and high levels of suicide. Yet it is also contributing to another increasingly urgent global emergency ‚Äì climate change. Here, an Embera indigenous girl carries her brother in Puesto Indio, a rural village in the Choco department of western Colombia, on Jan. 25, 2017. A recent¬†report on Colombia, Bolivia and Brazil found that ensuring indigenous communities legally own their traditional territories could avert between 42.8 and 59.7 megatons of carbon emissions over a 20-year period. Click the link in our bio to read more about how indigenous people may be the key to slowing climate change. (üì∑: Luis Robayo/AFP/Getty Images)

Jim Strickland has always considered himself a cowboy. His family has been raising cattle in Florida since the Civil War, and after his father passed away unexpectedly when Strickland was 17, he inherited the family business. He estimates he now oversees about 18,000 acres of land across the Sunshine State's Manatee, DeSoto, Levy and Marion counties. Yet deeply seated within Strickland's ranching roots is a desire to preserve the wild Florida he grew up with, an area he's seen chipped away over the last 60 years ‚Äì and especially in the last decade ‚Äì by land development and population growth from all directions. Click the link in our bio for more on how ranchers like Strickland are seeking restrictions on their land to preserve wild Florida and their livestock legacies. (üì∑: @katethegreat1012)

In Peoria's black neighborhoods, like the East Bluff or South Side, poverty, drugs and fast-food restaurants are abundant, while the fundamentals of a healthy lifestyle ‚Äì access to fresh food, quality health insurance, basic knowledge of how to stay healthy ‚Äì are scarce. In Tazewell County ‚Äì just across the Illinois River from Peoria, seat of the county of the same name and home to some 60 percent of county residents ‚Äì the scene is far different. In the Tazewell commercial hub of East Peoria, a bustling mashup of town square, shopping plaza and city park called The Levee District lies within sight of the downtown Peoria skyline, its gray and gritty twin. Though Tazewell County is among the nation‚Äôs top 200 Healthiest Communities, according to U.S. News & World Report rankings, Peoria County didn‚Äôt make the cut. Residents from both counties shared their thoughts on the differences between their communities. Click the link in our bio to read what they said. (üì∑: @joshualott)

Hugh R. Brown, owner of Brown's Hardware, poses for a portrait outside the neighborhood hardware store in Falls Church, Virginia on March 17, 2018. "Been here for 77 years. Falls Church has been good to me. Enjoyed living here," he says. The Little City‚Äô in northern Virginia is No. 1 in the inaugural U.S. News Healthiest Communities rankings. Just days after Kylie Mohr's September 2017 due date, her blood pressure rose and labor was induced to hasten the birth. Over the next 48 hours, Mohr's seemingly by-the-book pregnancy turned into a cascade of life-threatening complications. Her blood pressure suddenly spiked out of control, leading to an emergency cesarean section, hemorrhaging and kidney failure. The 28-year-old Georgia Air National Guardsman had to be transferred to a trauma center, and she spent five days in intensive care before holding her healthy infant son Lincoln, plus three more days in the hospital. She continues to live with the consequences of her traumatic birth experience. "Instead of being happy every time I see a pregnant woman, I just want to say, 'Good luck,'" Mohr says. Dangerous baby deliveries are a deadly trend in the U.S. Click the link in our bio for more on how states are trying to stop it. (üì∑: @amandagreenephotographs)

Sept. 15, 2018, marks the 10-year anniversary of the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. Some of the most jarring trauma for people in the financial industry came months after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy filing. When Timothy ‚ÄúPaule‚Äù Jackson got sick, no doctor or antibiotic treatment could get rid of his persistent cough. Then, he tried honey. ‚ÄúOnce we tried honey, I noticed that my cough had cleared up,‚Äù Jackson says. That's when his partner, Nicole Lindsey, suggested, "Hey, what if we brought beekeeping to Detroit?‚Äù What started out as a cold materialized into a pioneering effort to repurpose Detroit‚Äôs 72,173 vacant lots, one hive at a time. Jackson and Lindsey are now co-founders of @DetroitHives, a non-profit through which they create urban bee farms that sit at the crossroads of revitalization, sustainability and education. Life as we knew it in these United States ended that Tuesday morning. In the place where the World Trade Center once stood, black smoke billowed against a heartbreakingly blue sky. All who saw it knew immediately there would never be no place like home again. We would never again feel completely safe. We would never again know sanctuary. On September 11, 2001, America joined the rest of the world: Terror had come home to us. Today, America remembers the fallen 17 years later. Pictured here, family members visit the South Pool of the 9/11 Memorial at the World Trade Center site in New York City during the tenth anniversary ceremonies of terrorist attacks. Click the link in our bio to read ‚ÄúInnocence Lost Forever on 9/11‚Äù from the U.S. News archive in 2001. (üì∑: Todd Heisler/Getty Images/Pool)

The American dream of home ownership is becoming more elusive for low- and even middle-income Americans.¬†For former President Jimmy Carter, having a house is about more than having safe place to sleep. It's about community, a sense of belonging and the dignity that comes with building, maintaining ‚Äì and paying for, with some help ‚Äì a home of one's own.¬†At 93 (he'll be 94 Oct. 1), nearly 38 years since he lost his campaign for a second term, 50 years after the enactment of the Fair Housing Act, 35 years since the Carter Center began working with Habitat for Humanity, and 72 years since he married his wife and homebuilding partner, Rosalynn, Carter is still toiling away at what has become his life's work. Taking a brief break from a home-building project in Indiana, U.S. News spoke with Carter about where the nation has come and what it needs to do ‚Äì on housing and good governance. Click the link in our bio to read what he had to say. (üì∑: John Amis/AP and Robert Franklin/South Bend Tribune via AP)

On this day, 55 years ago, Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his ‚ÄúI Have a Dream‚Äù speech. At the March on Washington on Aug. 28, 1963, King declared, "I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up, live out the true meaning of its creed: 'We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal.'....I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. I have a dream today." Many Americans still do. U.S. News and World Report recently asked visitors to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial in Washington, D.C., to reflect on the current meaning of civil rights. LGBTQ rights. Police brutality. Immigration. Racial tension. What do civil rights mean to you? Click the link in our bio for more. (üì∑:¬†@bziegler)

War hero and Sen. John McCain has died following a battle with brain cancer, a day after his family announced his decision to discontinue treatment. He was 81. Cindy McCain, John‚Äôs wife, tweeted that ‚Äúhe passed the way he lived, on his own terms, surrounded by the people he loved, in the place he loved best.‚Äù The Arizona Republican is remembered for his six-term career in the U.S. Senate, his candidacy as the 2008 GOP presidential nominee and as a war hero who was held as a POW in North Vietnam after his plane was shot down on a bombing mission in 1967. McCain was diagnosed with a glioblastoma in July 2017. Click the link in our bio for more moments from the Arizona senator‚Äôs career through the lens of U.S. News & World Report photographers. (üì∑: Thomas J. O‚ÄôHalloran, Stephen R. Brown and Jim Lo Scalzo)

Sen. John McCain, who has been battling brain cancer, is discontinuing medical treatment, his family announced in a statement. The Arizona Republican was diagnosed with a glioblastoma in July 2017. Despite the poor prognosis, McCain, who turns 82 next week, "has surpassed expectations," the statement says. But due to the progression of the disease and his age, "he has now chosen to discontinue medical treatment." McCain, a prisoner of war during the Vietnam War for more than five years, has become a stalwart of the Republican Party with a career that spans six terms in the U.S. Senate and includes a 2008 run as the GOP presidential nominee. Support for McCain poured across social media Friday. Click the link in our bio for more moments from the Arizona senator's career through the lens of U.S. News & World Report photographers. (üì∑: Charlie Archambault)

Thomas Stanley Ricketts thinks he has suffered the effects of a traumatic brain injury since infancy. "I can‚Äôt complain, I had a very happy childhood," Mercedes Villalobos del Tio says as she displays a photo of herself with her mom.¬†The 61-year-old was raised an only child, and it wasn‚Äôt until she was 50 years old that she learned from her father, who was on his deathbed, that she was adopted.¬†But when Villalobos del Tio and her husband looked into her adoption papers, something was off. Villalobos del Tio may have been one of the roughly 300,000 babies allegedly stolen from their mothers in Spain between 1939 and the late 1980s. The practice began at the end of the Spanish Civil War, when the late dictator Francisco Franco rose to power. A winner in the National Press Photographers Association 2018 quarterly competition: Rising Sea Levels Threaten Maryland‚Äôs Eastern Shore. Photographer Greg Kahn has been documenting sea level rise in Maryland‚Äôs Eastern shore for the past five years. ‚ÄúA dramatic natural disaster will capture our attention, inspire us to action, and then recede to the background of our lives,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúOn Maryland‚Äôs Eastern Shore, the natural disaster is a long, drawn-out event ‚Äì a rising sea level occurring at the rate of three millimeters per year ‚Äì slow enough to ignore, but dramatic enough to overtake the town in 50 years. Raising the revenue to rebuild and repair the country's infrastructure is not easy and there is disagreement on how to pay for it. Some think the federal gas tax needs to be hiked. The federal taxes subsidize the Highway Trust Fund, which pays for roads' construction, other surface transportation projects and some mass transit. Raising the tax is especially unpopular in rural states with high vehicle usage. Others, such as experts at the libertarian Reason Foundation, think driver user fees are the fairest ‚Äì and the most sustainable, since hybrid and electric cars will shift more of the burden to motorists with gasoline-powered vehicles. Click the link in our bio for more on the state of transportation in America. (üì∑: @bziegler)

A disparate group of transportation experts, politicians across the spectrum and economists agree: American infrastructure is in bad shape. The American Society of Civil Engineers gave it a "D-plus" in its most recent quadrennial report in 2017. And the estimated cost of bringing things up to speed and up to date ‚Äì a cool $1.2 trillion over the next decade, ASCE estimates ‚Äì is almost as jarring as the cost of doing nothing. States are bridging the gap in federal funding. Click the link in our bio for more on the state of transportation in America. (üì∑: Jim Lo Scalzo for USN&WR)
